entry.title: The Myth of the Magic Bullet
entry.summary: While much remains unknown about the motives of the would-be assassin in Butler, Pennsylvania, one thing is certain. The man who attempted to kill Donald Trump believed his bullet would change the course of history for the better. Such thinking is common and is promoted in most school books that exhort young people to be better citizens by featuring the stories of national heroes who have changed the world. The killer‚Äôs belief that murdering a political leader could improve the nation was the logical converse of this mistaken principle. More The post The Myth of the Magic Bullet appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: Warning From the Edge of the Abyss
entry.summary: Two sets of events, which have important echoes today, precipitated the Cuban Missile Crisis.¬† The US had moved Jupiter medium-range nuclear missile systems into Turkey, prompting the Soviets to take countermeasures, including preparing to station missiles in Cuba and send Ilyushin jet bombers to the island.¬† Kennedy and the Americans were understandably deeply concerned about this breach of the Monroe Doctrine and the very real threat it posed.¬† More The post Warning From the Edge of the Abyss appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

148 years ago this week, on April 6, 1871, armed participants in the revolutionary Paris Commune seized the guillotine that was stored near the prison in Paris. They brought it to the foot of the statue of Voltaire, where they smashed it into pieces and burned it in a bonfire, to the applause of an immense crowd.[1] This was a popular action arising from the grassroots, not a spectacle coordinated by politicians. entry.title: my issue with online interactions
entry.summary: The longer I am off of any social media and not constantly bombarded with the language and digital mannerisms inherent to it, the more I notice how odd it feels to detect that kind of language in others outside of those timelines and feeds. I am active in very few Discord servers and most of them are small, friends-only groups. However, in the few public ones I am in, I often see groups of people whose choices of words and how to express themselves, how to enter conversations, their tone and views make them feel eerily... unreal. I've thought about it, and the best way I could describe it is as if someone trained AI on the most active Twitter users. There is a specific flavor of overly cool, casually careless, sarcastic, flippant, at times vitriolic undertone to everything that is hard to ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is the EPA Hiding at the Landfill in Uniontown, Ohio?
entry.summary:
Image by Koushik Chowdavarapu. THE TWILIGHT ZONE ‚Äî Picture if you will the citizens of a small town in Northeast Ohio, facing a daunting toxic threat yet trapped in a maze of regulatory capture at the so-called Environmental Protection Agency. Not the citizens of East Palestine, though they too face a challenging quest for the truth about the environmental health threats they may face. But the citizens in and around Uniontown, Ohio have been trapped in such a quagmire for decades, subjected to a dystopian level of gaslighting from the powers that be in an effort to bury the truth regarding the ultra-hazardous poisons reportedly dumped at the town landfill. The Industrial Excess Landfill (IEL) in Uniontown closed in 1980 and was designated as an EPA Superfund site in 1984, listed as one of the most contaminated sites in the country. Akron area rubber companies were the biggest known polluters at the IEL, dumping millions of gallons of industrial waste and chemicals in the ‚Äò60s and ‚Äò70s. But local citizen eyewitnesses have long testified that the U.S. military was another covert client in the late ‚Äò60s/early ‚Äò70s. This includes the IEL‚Äôs former owner Charles Kittinger, who came forward in 2001 to speak of clandestine dumping of three metal eggs of nuclear weapons waste he was eerily warned not to speak of. here or subscribe here. If you are logged in but can't read CP+ articles, check the status of your access here In order to read CP+ articles, your web browser must be set to accept cookies.
More The post What is the EPA Hiding at the Landfill in Uniontown, Ohio? appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: You Are Not Alone if You Are Out of Work
entry.summary:
Image by Hennie Stander. We are endlessly and repetitively treated to sermons on the wonders of capitalism. Everybody will be taken care of, with the proviso that you are willing to work. As I have had frequent cause to note, that a line has to be furiously propagated across every channel speaks to a lack of concrete reality. And as more people, especially young people, see that they have declining possibilities, more questioning inevitably arises. The only thing worse in capitalism to having a job, however unpleasant, is not having a job. Unemployment benefits are barely at starvation rates and end all too soon. Naturally, that is worse in the United States than most other advanced capitalist countries of the Global North. Six months is the limit set at a rate well less than half of what your wages were in the job you just lost. And given that six months is the average time necessary to secure new employment, that means around half of those collecting unemployment insurance will likely have a spell of no income at all. here or subscribe here. If you are logged in but can't read CP+ articles, check the status of your access here In order to read CP+ articles, your web browser must be set to accept cookies.
More The post You Are Not Alone if You Are Out of Work appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: reacquainting myself with my first love
entry.summary: This time around in New York I've not been diligently documenting where I've been and gone to eat. Part of me says who cares, nobody actually pays attention anyway and you don't look back much either. The other thinks I'll regret it in the future. I'm making my way through Joan Didion's essay "On Keeping a Notebook" from Slouching Towards Bethlehem; some of the passages in there comfort me: Why did I write it down? In order to remember, of course, but exactly what was it I wanted to remember? How much of it actually happened? Did any of it? Why do I keep a notebook at all? It is easy to deceive oneself on all those scores. The impulse to write things down is a peculiarly compulsive one, inexplicable to those who do not share it, useful only accidentally, only secondarily, in the way that a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ramblings and Saturday Musings
entry.summary:
It took me a while to get settled into this particular space of mine on the Interwebs. I didn't know what I wanted out of it, but over time (past few months) it just kind of grew into its own thing. Notes by JCProbably started out as just a place for scrappy thoughts, and scattered notes. Nothing too serious. It was hosted on a different platform, while what I called my "primary" blog (titled: With Love, JCProbably) was hosted in another1. That one included my microposts that I labeled as musings. When starting this Notes subdomain, I initially said2 I'm hoping to use this page as a more scattered note, a digital post-it of some sort, when I think of things... and possibly just start linking more coherent thoughts when I write my Week Notes to it. After the May challenge, I started writing more in this space. By June, I transferred it to Bear (where you're reading this now), and I'm in a much more comfortable space when it comes to writing and blogging. Anyways, all of this to say that I am also looking into (re)adding my short-form thoughts and musings here (to consolidate everything). I've come to accept that I don't need to always have a long-winded post about a specific topic on here. Sometimes I really just want to write a few sentences about how I'm feeling, or ponder on some thoughts, and calling it a day. These posts will be tagged #musings ‚Äî in case you were curious (but probably not). And no, those will (hopefully) not be as long as this ended up to be. I'm also hoping to include just every day photos that are a little bit more casual3 than what I post on my site specifically for photos. Okay, that's it. Seriously. 10/100 One tenth done with 100DaysToOffload! Reply by email It still is, but I haven't been wanting to go on there lately, so I'm not even going to link it on here.‚Ü©
Original post did not make it through the migration process.‚Ü©
Veronique has been my inspiration on this front, if I'm being honest. I love how she incorporates just daily photos in her posts. Go check out her blog and posts!‚Ü©

entry.title: I'm ditching spotify
entry.summary:
spotify is legal piracy. you can listen to most of your music by just paying a small amount and most of that doesn't go to the artist. hell with the rise of AI, enshittification got to a level that it never has before. I just don't want to be a part of that anymore. there is also another reason I'm doing this. having physical files of your collection feels great. you can take your music collection anywhere you want, convert it to any format you wish and use any music player you fancy. it is at times a bit time consuming but I enjoy growing my collection and not having to throw money at a faceless company just to keep listening to my music.
how I manage it I download most of my music as flacs then convert it to opus at 160kbps. the ones I couldn't get as flacs stay as mp3s. I store them in an SD card and use poweramp as my music app. I am not really settled on it yet, so recommendations are welcome. I use last.fm and regular old internet browsing for recommendations. I never really used spotifys recommendation algorithm to begin with, because i value a passionate music fans words more than an algorithm. notes you can also take a look at kit's post for an artists perspective on why spotify is shitty as a platform. kit puts it into words better than I ever could. reply via email liked this post? you can follow my rss feed for more. i'd also appreciate if you toasted this post below. üçû

entry.title: Don't think too much
entry.summary: Yesterday I was watching a Swedish music documentary. In one of the scenes, the artist Errol (aka Eddie Meduza) says: If you think too much, you go crazy. Take life as it comes. True words ‚Äî and all too easy to forget. We put so much emphasis on thinking in our modern society that the gut feeling, the inner vibe, has been overshadowed. We think like crazy, even in moments when thinking brings nothing but confusion and fatigue. Thinking has an important role, of course. We can make great use of this ability to plan, prepare, and make calculated decisions. But often the best thing we can do is "take life as it comes."

entry.title: Techninal Blog/Notes
entry.summary: So, these wont be the traditional notes where you write down your understanding or something. No. Never worked for me. Too boring and I never actually read again. What works is just having a bunch of questions that I can answer again and understand. So thats what it would be. Do it with your favorite llm for additional fun but take the effort to answer yourself first. That is the point. entry.title: V. S. Lozovyi - Far-left agrarianist peasant-centric discourse

Author: V. S. entry.title: Tariffs Don‚Äôt Protect Jobs. Don‚Äôt Be Fooled.
entry.summary: Both Trump and Biden imposed high tariffs on imported products made in China and other countries. Those impositions broke with and departed from the previous half century‚Äôs policies favoring ‚Äúfree trade‚Äù (less or minimal government intervention in international markets). Free trade policies facilitated ‚Äúglobalization,‚Äù the euphemism for the post-1970 surge in U.S. corporations‚Äô investing abroad: producing and distributing there, re-locating operations there, and merging with foreign enterprises there. More The post Tariffs Don‚Äôt Protect Jobs. Don‚Äôt Be Fooled. appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: The American Enabling Act
entry.summary: Hitler‚Äôs ultimate rise to power was the result neither of a popular vote nor a coup, but an ‚ÄúEnabling Act,‚Äù or more precisely, ‚ÄúThe Law to Remedy the Distress of the People and the Reich.‚Äù The legislation submitted to the German Reichstag (parliament) on March 23, 1933, enabled Hitler and his cabinet to 1) make laws without participation of the Reichstag; 2) enact measures that violated the German constitution; 3) implement new laws immediately; 4) allow the government to make foreign treaties without input from the Reichstag; and 5) sunset the act after four years. More The post The American Enabling Act appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: The torture of being exposed to people who live on a totally different frequency
entry.summary:
There are some people around us who live on a totally different frequency, especially in the work environment. They never shut up. They always seek a chance to talk to you. They don't let you have a peaceful and silent moment. They talk but don't say anything. They do not understand that we just need peaceful and silent moment. They do not understand that we don't like them. They expect attention and response. It is hell when I see them around. I just cannot escape. I usually try to put my headphones on and listen to music at full volume. But this time, they wave their hand at me to talk to me - and in that moment I want to scream. It does not matter if you give them very short answers and ignore. They never stop.
Because of this, I developed a habit of looking at the floor so that I won't have eye contact with them. Sometimes I close my eyes and pretend to be sleeping. It's so difficult to be kind sometimes.
My social battery is already pretty weak and people who live on a different frequency are just torturing my soul. People like me should work at a cave or something like that. I lose my sanity when I want peaceful moment while having no escape.

entry.title: country diary
entry.summary:
My apartment doesn't have power. They're doing some kind of maintenance. The air is hot and thick, and I'm pining for some AC. Took the doggo out for our morning walk and stopped at Timmies to get a coffee and breakfast sandwich, then remembered I had to walk up four flights of stairs bc‚Äîno power. K drove me back to the city last night, and as much as I miss being in the country...coming home to my own apartment and bed felt nice. As I was falling asleep, I saw the tiniest of ants crawling up my arm, and immediately murder, death, kill for that little guy and of course I then googled what would happen if an ant crawled into your ear and nothing good came out of that. I distracted myself by watching some ASMR and fell asleep in my perfectly temperature-controlled bedroom (K's apartment is a veritable icebox). ** his mom crocheted me a shawl(!!!), and I think my heart imploded. Nothing says i love you more than here...I made you something. &nbsp country sunsets & trails
the trail where I got devoured by an army of carnivorous mosquitos
out-the-car-window photographs

entry.title: The Mysterious Slowdown in U.S. Manufacturing Productivity
entry.summary: Throughout the twentieth century, steady technological and organizational innovations, along with the accumulation of productive capital, increased labor productivity at a steady rate of around 2¬†percent per year. However, the past two decades have witnessed a slowdown in labor productivity, measured as value added per hour worked. This slowdown has been particularly stark in the manufacturing sector, which historically has been a leading sector in driving the productivity of the aggregate U.S. economy. What makes this slowdown particularly puzzling is the fact that manufacturing accounts for the majority of U.S. research and development (R&D) expenditure. Despite several recent studies (see, for example, Syverson [2016]), much remains to be uncovered about the nature of this slowdown. This post illustrates a key facet of the mystery: the productivity slowdown appears to be pervasive across industries and across firms of various sizes.

entry.title: Trading Buckets
entry.summary: These are the buckets that matter ü™£ If your trading is not dropped into one of these buckets, you are probably going to struggle. Month after month, the money is made within these buckets. If you spend most of your time outside of these buckets, you probably aren't making much progress, getting lucky, or you have some structural edge such as a large following, a broker that provides you with the midpoint or better on the majority of your fills, or some dumbass CFD "broker" that allows you to hit the bid on stocks on SSR with unlimited size without impacting the market... This is where the money is being made, this is where the focus ought to be. If you think you can reinvent the wheel or feel the need to do so, you are wasting your time. The best trades and the best traders make the most ‚Ä¶

By "Anjin" is meant here spiritual calmness created by Prajna. Prajna is a unique intuition that sees the true nature of things as they are (Yathabhutam). "Zazen-shin" (Âùê Á¶Ö ÁÆ¥, Instruction in Zazen) by Dogen (1200 -1253) reads: "A bird flies as a bird does; a fish swims likes a fish!" The essence of things seen by Prajna or Yathatathyadarsana (Â¶Ç ÂÆü Ë¶ã, seeing into the truth as it is) is named "Suchness" (tathata) or "Emptiness" (sunyata), because it is beyond our daily expression which is the result of discriminative consciousness ‚Ä¶

entry.title: True Confessions - My Life on the High Seas
entry.summary: Those of us whose online life began with 2400 bps modems or slower remember what life was like when viewing an image online meant downloading it line by line over a 10- or 15-minute period. One image. The early editions of CompuServe, Prodigy, and AOL were all text-based, as were local BBSs. When the real Internet, the kind you access through a browser, or rather through Netscape 1.0, became available, for me in 1996, most of us had 14.4 modems; we quickly upgraded to 28.8 and then 56.6 bps. When things were still super slow, I remember downloading Netscape 2.0 like it was the birth of another child. It was about 6 MB in size, and it took 45 minutes of "NOBODY CAN USE THE PHONE." I paced back and forth outside on my lawn, smoking cigarettes and trying to imagine what the new web would look‚Ä¶

The Zapatista indigenous movement in Chiapas, M√©xico has summarized many of their principles into short, accessible sayings that convey big ideas about a different way of leading and building power, which contrast greatly with repressive/oppressive methods of holding power and authority. Mandar Obedeciendo (Lead by Obeying) PRINCIPLE: True leaders follow the will of the people, the desires of the larger community. PRACTICE: This principle challenges authoritarianism in the communities, and representatives who are not accountable to the widespread desires of the community will be ousted from their positions. In many of the communities, an oversig‚Ä¶

entry.title: TheOffer.txt
entry.summary: We're Buying a House i am absolutely exploding inside with this news, but i have no way to scream it, so this will have to do. we've put an offer in on a house on sunday, and they accepted it today! i cannot believe it! i cried all the two hours it took for us to get home; partially because this is a dream that i have worked so hard for and never thought i'd actually get. the house is deeply within our budget, thank goodness; but it's pushing the limits of commute for my boyfriend, which is unfortunate. i wish it was still affordable to live within reasonable commuting distance of a major city like seattle, but i'm just so thankful that we're staying in the pacific northwest. i'm really loving every second of being here, and it feels as though i was always meant to be here in this moment‚Äîi‚Ä¶

A short poem ‚ÄúAdoring Naivety‚Äù by a Christian poet Jukichi Yagi (1827‚Äì1927) runs as follows: Rice bread, Whole-rice bread, Fresh and steaming! Whole-rice bread! A bread seller goes about a ‚ÄúNon-acting‚Äù (Mu-i ÁÑ° Áà≤ akarma) path singing cries of wares, as if in ecstacy over his singing.[1] This verse seems to suggest the aesthetic character of the Japanese folks. In the early days, Japanese peddlers, such as gold-fish vendors, beancurd dealers and seedling-peddlers used to peddle by crying in rythmical voices. Mood, relish, flavour and atmosphere carry great weight in a Japanese life. ‚ÄúJapanese ph‚Ä¶

entry.title: Kostas Sakkas - Political statement at the terror-trial of Koridallos prison
entry.summary:
Author: Kostas Sakkas Title: Political statement at the terror-trial of Koridallos prison Date: January 14, 2015, anarchists in trouble Source: <actforfree.nostate.net/?p=18709>. Retrieved on 03/07/2024 from lib.anarhija.net.
I am sending the following text to Athens lawyer Dimitrios Katsaris in order for him to deliver it to his client and my co-accused Giorgos Karagiannidis, in order to read it out in the courtroom during the testimony procedure. I realize absolutely that what a relative of mine testified during the witnesses‚Äô testimonies was done with the best of intentions. However I must clarify that a large part of it does not reflect reality and does not express me as an individual. Unfortunately the conditions in which I find myself in, my inability to communicate and the restr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Clarence Lee Swartz, in collaboration with The Mutualist Associates - What Is Mutualism?
entry.summary:
Author: Clarence Lee Swartz, in collaboration with The Mutualist Associates Title: What Is Mutualism? Date: 1927 Notes: This is a very interesting and valuable text on Mutualism. It is slightly dated in some points and a bit off the target when dealing with monetary matters. Nevertheless it remains a powerful exposition of the main tenets of Mutualism and a sincere plea in favour of the freedom and autonomy of the individual. Source: <c4ss.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/what-is-mutualism.pdf>
MUTUALISM ‚Äî A Social System Based on Equal Freedom, Reciprocity, and the Sovereignty of the Individual Over Himself, His Affairs, and His Products; Realized Through Individual Initiative, Free Contract, Cooperation, Competition, and Voluntary Association for Defense Against the Invasive and for the P‚Ä¶

entry.title: A Reminder to Take a Walk and Breathe
entry.summary: A non-stressful day at work is hard to come by. I am constantly straddling the fine line between being burnt out, and just flipping a table and walking away. At the end of the day, those two feelings are basically the same side of a coin. I work remotely full-time, for the most part. Sometimes I travel for workshops, but that‚Äôs mostly just at the beginning of kicking off a new product that I‚Äôve been asked to build. Any other time, I‚Äôm mostly working in my home office, which has become my favorite place in the house, yet the place where I stress out the most. I spend a lot of time in front of a computer. I‚Äôm in meetings probably 5-6 hours a day. With a majority of my current team in Central and Eastern time zones (2-3 hours ahead of me), sometimes I also forget to take a break and eat. It‚Äôs easy to lose track of time when I‚Äôm focused on solving this problem or that. I also forget to breathe. The weather finally cooled down yesterday, and a little bit today before we hit another heat wave. LSC constantly encourages me, and at times pushes me to go for a walk. Take a walk around the block, and just breathe. We practice breathing together, inhaling and exhaling. Inhale the fresh air slowly, keep it in for a few seconds, exhale slowly. Then we go back in the house, and I feel a tiny bit better. Sometimes we get into what we‚Äôre doing so deeply that we forget the essentials. We forget to breathe. We don‚Äôt notice it until we‚Äôre drowning, and it‚Äôs even harder to get back to the surface. Sometimes all it takes is a reminder to stop what you‚Äôre doing, take a walk if you can, and breathe. So hey, let this be a reminder. Go for a walk. Inhale that fresh air. Hold it in. Exhale. 7/100 Reply by email

entry.title: Exploring the challenges in creating an accessible sortable list (drag-and-drop)
entry.summary:
Drag-and-drop is a highly interactive and visual interface. We often use drag-and-drop to perform tasks like uploading files, reordering browser bookmarks, or even moving a card in solitaire.

The post Exploring the challenges in creating an accessible sortable list (drag-and-drop) appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

entry.title: morning commute
entry.summary: hello! it‚Äôs been a while since anything at all. june wasn‚Äôt uneventful or anything (quite the opposite, really!). i was just lost for words and it‚Äôs taken me some time to find them again ‚Äì life lately has felt like a lot, when it really shouldn‚Äôt have been. i‚Äôve finally started a new job after my month-long vacation in europe. i‚Äôm still working in design, which is still not really my ideal (even if my high-school self was convinced it was)1. either way, it‚Äôs fun and i like it better than my previous one. my last job was 100% remote. (they were changing this policy just as i was leaving though). i enjoyed having so much free time, of course. the commute in the philippines eats away up to 4 hours of your day, if you‚Äôre lucky. that‚Äôs not including time you spend getting ready, or time spent s‚Ä¶

entry.summary: Welcome to the 18th edition of the Cloudflare DDoS Threat Report. Released quarterly, these reports provide an in-depth analysis of the DDoS threat landscape as observed across the Cloudflare network. This edition focuses on the second quarter of 2024

entry.title: RADIUS/UDP vulnerable to improved MD5 collision attack
entry.summary: The RADIUS protocol is commonly used to control administrative access to networking gear. Despite its importance, RADIUS hasn‚Äôt changed much in decades. We discuss an attack on RADIUS as a case study for why it‚Äôs important for legacy protocols to keep up with advancements in cryptography

entry.title: Is climate change increasing the strength of Australian red wine?
entry.summary: Apparently red wines made in Australia ‚Äî and quite possibly elsewhere, I imagine ‚Äî have been increasing in alcoholic strength over recent decades. This seems like a mystery of the times, because the go-to culprit, global warming, may not be responsible. Rather, the way grapes are grown, and changes in fermenting methods ‚Äî which apparently [‚Ä¶]
